A CT scan of the abdomen with IV contrast is the most appropriate initial test to confirm or rule out these diagnoses. We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest malabsorption syndrome, and the big clue is the greasy stools which leave a residue in the toilet bowl, indicating the presence of undigested fat. The patient’s history of alcohol consumption is also a possible contributing factor. The next step in diagnosis is therefore to order a CT abdomen with IV contrast to evaluate the pancreatic or hepatobiliary system. An EGD with biopsy of gastric mucosa can help diagnose Helicobacter pylori infection and gastritis, but it is not the most appropriate next step in this patient with malabsorption symptoms. The d-xylose absorption test and somatostatin receptor scintigraphy are used for other conditions and are not necessary at this point in the diagnostic workup.

The d-xylose absorption test is used to assess for malabsorption syndrome, EGD with biopsy of gastric mucosa is used to evaluate for gastritis or peptic ulcer disease, and somatostatin receptor scintigraphy is used to detect neuroendocrine tumors.
